articles.headline: It’s Hard Work to Make Ordering Groceries Online So Easy
articles.snippet: The technology needed to fulfill orders is costly for stores, and the workers who pick items off the shelves often feel the pressure of being tracked.
articles.abstract: The technology needed to fulfill orders is costly for stores, and the workers who pick items off the shelves often feel the pressure of being tracked.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nick Fraser would regularly start his grocery picking shifts at the local Fred Meyer store at 4 or 5 a.m.

articles.headline: Facebook Says Trump’s Ban Will Last at Least 2 Years
articles.snippet: The decision denies the former president a megaphone at least through the midterm elections. The suspension was put in place after the Capitol riot in January.
articles.abstract: The decision denies the former president a megaphone at least through the midterm elections. The suspension was put in place after the Capitol riot in January.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook said on Friday that Donald J. Trump’s suspension from the service would last at least two years, keeping the former president off mainstream social media for the 2022 midterm elections, as the company also said it would end a policy of treating posts from politicians differently from those of other users.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: White House Embraces Job Growth but Distances Itself From Expanded Benefits
articles.snippet: As Republicans blame enhanced unemployment insurance for slower-than-expected job gains, the White House stresses that the benefit will expire in September as planned.
articles.abstract: As Republicans blame enhanced unemployment insurance for slower-than-expected job gains, the White House stresses that the benefit will expire in September as planned.
articles.lead_paragraph: With fresh data showing that American employers added jobs at a decent but unexceptional pace in May, President Biden on Friday emphasized that his administration would not try to extend enhanced unemployment benefits that Republicans have criticized as a key factor in fueling a labor shortage.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Black Lives Matter Has Grown More Powerful, and More Divided
articles.snippet: Since the murder of George Floyd, the racial justice movement has received millions of dollars in donations. But some chapters have questioned how those funds are spent.
articles.abstract: Since the murder of George Floyd, the racial justice movement has received millions of dollars in donations. But some chapters have questioned how those funds are spent.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the year since George Floyd was murdered, racial justice organizations across the country have been inundated with millions of dollars in donations and thousands of eager new activists. They have earned a prominent platform that puts them on the front lines of political and social battles.

articles.headline: U.S. Waged Secret Legal Battle to Obtain Emails of 4 Times Reporters
articles.snippet: The push began in the Trump administration and continued under President Biden, and the Justice Department obtained a gag order to keep it from public view.
articles.abstract: The push began in the Trump administration and continued under President Biden, and the Justice Department obtained a gag order to keep it from public view.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the last weeks of the Trump administration and continuing under President Biden, the Justice Department fought a secret legal battle to obtain the email logs of four New York Times reporters in a hunt for their sources, a top lawyer for the newspaper said Friday night.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Katie Benner

articles.headline: The Best Investment of All: The People You Love the Most
articles.snippet: If you’re emerging from the pandemic in better financial shape than before, ask yourself this: What will you spend to renew your bonds, and how will you do it?
articles.abstract: If you’re emerging from the pandemic in better financial shape than before, ask yourself this: What will you spend to renew your bonds, and how will you do it?
articles.lead_paragraph: In early 2013, three years after the unexpected death of her husband, Chanel Reynolds posted a warning to those who had neglected the bonds that ought to matter most.

articles.headline: Federal Unemployment Aid Is Now a Political Lightning Rod
articles.snippet: Republican-led states are cutting off relief months ahead of schedule, citing openings aplenty. Some jobless workers face hardships and tough choices.
articles.abstract: Republican-led states are cutting off relief months ahead of schedule, citing openings aplenty. Some jobless workers face hardships and tough choices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of the more than four million people whose jobless benefits are going to be cut off in the next few weeks, Bre Starr will be among the first.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: As Vaccines Turn Pandemic’s Tide, U.S. and Europe Diverge on Path Forward
articles.snippet: The split is particularly stark in Britain, which is facing the spread of a new variant, while America has essentially lifted all rules for people who are vaccinated.
articles.abstract: The split is particularly stark in Britain, which is facing the spread of a new variant, while America has essentially lifted all rules for people who are vaccinated.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Over Memorial Day weekend, 135,000 people jammed the oval at the Indianapolis 500. Restaurants across the United States were thronged with customers as mask mandates were being discarded.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mueller and Marc Santora

articles.headline: Are We Waiting for Everyone to Get Hacked?
articles.snippet: It’s been almost a decade since Leon Panetta, then the secretary of defense, warned of an impending “Cyber Pearl Harbor.” He didn’t want to be right.
articles.abstract: It’s been almost a decade since Leon Panetta, then the secretary of defense, warned of an impending “Cyber Pearl Harbor.” He didn’t want to be right.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTEREY, Calif. — Leon Panetta is one of the few American government officials who can look around at the nation’s rolling cyberdisasters and justifiably say, “I told you so.”

articles.headline: Finance Leaders Reach Global Tax Deal Aimed at Ending Profit Shifting
articles.snippet: The Group of 7 nations agreed to back a new global minimum tax rate that companies would have to pay regardless of where they are based.
articles.abstract: The Group of 7 nations agreed to back a new global minimum tax rate that companies would have to pay regardless of where they are based.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The top economic officials from the world’s advanced economies reached a breakthrough on Saturday in their yearslong efforts to overhaul international tax laws, unveiling a broad agreement that aims to stop large multinational companies from seeking out tax havens and force them to pay more of their income to governments.

articles.headline: Meadows Pressed Justice Dept. to Investigate Election Fraud Claims
articles.snippet: Emails show the increasingly urgent efforts by President Trump and his allies during his last days in office to find some way to undermine, or even nullify, the election results.
articles.abstract: Emails show the increasingly urgent efforts by President Trump and his allies during his last days in office to find some way to undermine, or even nullify, the election results.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Donald J. Trump’s final weeks in office, Mark Meadows, his chief of staff, repeatedly pushed the Justice Department to investigate unfounded conspiracy theories about the 2020 presidential election, according to newly uncovered emails provided to Congress, portions of which were reviewed by The New York Times.

articles.headline: Thousands Descend on Miami to Glorify Bitcoin
articles.snippet: It was the largest Bitcoin event in the world and the first major in-person crypto conference since the pandemic started. The jargon, the liquor and the millionaire talk flowed.
articles.abstract: It was the largest Bitcoin event in the world and the first major in-person crypto conference since the pandemic started. The jargon, the liquor and the millionaire talk flowed.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — There was money in the air. Buzzwords floated around, like NFT, BTD, blockchain, token. There was a frenzied energy.

articles.headline: U.S. Aid to Central America Hasn’t Slowed Migration. Can Kamala Harris?
articles.snippet: A stark reality faces the vice president as she visits the region: Expanded aid programs have failed to stem migration.
articles.abstract: A stark reality faces the vice president as she visits the region: Expanded aid programs have failed to stem migration.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO HUISTA, Guatemala — An American contractor went to a small town in the Guatemalan mountains with an ambitious goal: to ignite the local economy, and hopefully even persuade people not to migrate north to the United States.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff, Michael D. Shear and Daniele Volpe

articles.headline: The Cost of Being an ‘Interchangeable Asian’
articles.snippet: At some top companies, Asian Americans are overrepresented in midlevel roles and underrepresented in leadership. The root of this workplace inequality could stem from the all-too-common experience of being confused for someone else.
articles.abstract: At some top companies, Asian Americans are overrepresented in midlevel roles and underrepresented in leadership. The root of this workplace inequality could stem from the all-too-common experience of being confused for someone else.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: A Federal College Loan Program Can Trap Parents in Debt
articles.snippet: The popular parent PLUS loans are made without regard to the ability of borrowers to repay, and have fewer protections when they can’t.
articles.abstract: The popular parent PLUS loans are made without regard to the ability of borrowers to repay, and have fewer protections when they can’t.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kate Schweizer and her husband didn’t want their two daughters, just 13 months apart, to begin their adult lives saddled with college debt, so they borrowed much of the money themselves. Beginning in 2005, the couple took out a new batch of federal loans each academic year, eventually accumulating about $220,000 in debt.

articles.headline: Manchin Vows to Block Democratic Voting Rights Bill and Preserve Filibuster
articles.snippet: Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, appeared to slam the door on the far-reaching measure when he wrote that he would not vote for any partisan voting bill.
articles.abstract: Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, appeared to slam the door on the far-reaching measure when he wrote that he would not vote for any partisan voting bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia said on Sunday in no uncertain terms that he would not vote for the Democrats’ far-reaching bill to combat voter suppression, nor would he ever end the legislative filibuster, a written promise that imperils much of President Biden’s agenda.

articles.headline: Once a Bastion of Free Speech, the A.C.L.U. Faces an Identity Crisis
articles.snippet: An organization that has defended the First Amendment rights of Nazis and the Ku Klux Klan is split by an internal debate over whether supporting progressive causes is more important.
articles.abstract: An organization that has defended the First Amendment rights of Nazis and the Ku Klux Klan is split by an internal debate over whether supporting progressive causes is more important.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be the celebration of a grand career, as the American Civil Liberties Union presented a prestigious award to the longtime lawyer David Goldberger. He had argued one of its most famous cases, defending the free speech rights of Nazis in the 1970s to march in Skokie, Ill., home to many Holocaust survivors.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Scrambles for New Approach in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The rapid withdrawal of U.S. troops has left the agency seeking ways to maintain its intelligence-gathering, war-fighting and counterterrorism operations in the country.
articles.abstract: The rapid withdrawal of U.S. troops has left the agency seeking ways to maintain its intelligence-gathering, war-fighting and counterterrorism operations in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The rapid U.S. military withdrawal from Afghanistan is creating intense pressure on the C.I.A. to find new ways to gather intelligence and carry out counterterrorism strikes in the country, but the agency has few good options.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Sweet Cherries, Bitter Politics: Two Farm Stands and the Nation’s Divides
articles.snippet: Opposing views of mask requirements have rippled across a Michigan county, even influencing where people buy their fruit.
articles.abstract: Opposing views of mask requirements have rippled across a Michigan county, even influencing where people buy their fruit.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELK RAPIDS, Mich. — The two farm stands lie just 12 miles apart along Route 31, a straight, flat road running through a bucolic wonderland of cherry orchards and crystalline lakes in northwestern Michigan.

articles.headline: Anthony Weiner’s Not Coming Back. But He Has Nowhere to Go.
articles.snippet: The man who was almost New York’s mayor talks about the current campaign, selling tweets and why he feels bad for the media.
articles.abstract: The man who was almost New York’s mayor talks about the current campaign, selling tweets and why he feels bad for the media.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anthony Weiner doesn’t pay the kind of attention to New York politics that he did back when he was running for mayor, twice, before the exchange of messages with a 15-year-old that sent him to federal prison.

articles.headline: Offshore Wind Farms Show What Biden’s Climate Plan Is Up Against
articles.snippet: The U.S. has fallen way behind Europe partly because of an old shipping law and opposition from homeowners and fishing groups.
articles.abstract: The U.S. has fallen way behind Europe partly because of an old shipping law and opposition from homeowners and fishing groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: A constellation of 5,400 offshore wind turbines meet a growing portion of Europe’s energy needs. The United States has exactly seven.

articles.headline: What Happened When Trump Was Banned on Social Media
articles.snippet: Since Facebook and Twitter banned him, Donald J. Trump, the former president, has posted statements online far less often. But some of his statements have traveled just as far and wide on social networks.
articles.abstract: Since Facebook and Twitter banned him, Donald J. Trump, the former president, has posted statements online far less often. But some of his statements have traveled just as far and wide on social networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since Facebook and Twitter banned him, Donald J. Trump, the former president, has posted statements online far less often. But some of his statements have traveled just as far and wide on social networks.
articles.byline: By Davey Alba, Ella Koeze and Jacob Silver

articles.headline: Why Amazon Is Confronting the Richest Man in India
articles.snippet: The American company sees big potential in the country’s nascent e-commerce market. Both sides view a troubled grocery store chain as the key to success.
articles.abstract: The American company sees big potential in the country’s nascent e-commerce market. Both sides view a troubled grocery store chain as the key to success.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Amazon and one of the world’s richest men are engaged in a multibillion-dollar, politically fraught clash over Rani Pillai’s favorite place to buy groceries.

articles.headline: In Arizona 2020 Election Review, Risks for Republicans, and Democracy
articles.snippet: Experts call it a circus. Polls say it will hurt the G.O.P. in 2022. But Republicans are on board in Arizona and elsewhere, despite warnings of lasting damage to the political system.
articles.abstract: Experts call it a circus. Polls say it will hurt the G.O.P. in 2022. But Republicans are on board in Arizona and elsewhere, despite warnings of lasting damage to the political system.
articles.lead_paragraph: SURPRISE, Ariz. — Rob Goins is 57, a former Marine and a lifelong Republican in a right-leaning jigsaw of golf courses, strip malls and gated retirement communities pieced together in the Arizona desert. But ask about the Republican-backed review of Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s 2020 election victory here in Maricopa County, and Mr. Goins rejects the party line.

articles.headline: Google to Pay $270 Million to Settle Antitrust Charges in France
articles.snippet: The tech giant, which is facing similar scrutiny in the U.S., also said it would make changes to increase transparency of its online ad systems.
articles.abstract: The tech giant, which is facing similar scrutiny in the U.S., also said it would make changes to increase transparency of its online ad systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Google agreed to pay roughly $270 million in fines and change some of its business practices as part of a settlement announced on Monday with French antitrust regulators who had accused the company of abusing its dominance of the online advertising market.

articles.headline: Jeff Bezos Will Fly Aboard Blue Origin’s First Human Trip to Space
articles.snippet: Mr. Bezos and his brother, Mark, will be on board when his rocket company launches its first human spaceflight next month, shortly after he steps down as chief executive of Amazon.
articles.abstract: Mr. Bezos and his brother, Mark, will be on board when his rocket company launches its first human spaceflight next month, shortly after he steps down as chief executive of Amazon.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the battle of billionaires with rocket companies, Jeff Bezos will finally beat Elon Musk.
articles.byline: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Kenneth Chang
